questions.text: What would you prefer to do on the weekend?

options.text: Refactor the code architecture of an old project
Create a smooth onboarding flow for new users
Improve how people interact with existing features

questions.text: When you see a cool new technology, what's your first reaction?

options.text: Check its stability and community support first
Immediately create a demo to try it out
Think about how to promote it within the team

questions.text: Which moment in programming do you enjoy most?

options.text: System running stably under high concurrency
Code becoming elegant and concise after refactoring
Solving a complex bug alone late at night

questions.text: What type of technical discussions do you prefer to participate in?

options.text: Sharing latest tech trends and tools
Discussing how to improve system reliability
Deep diving into algorithms and architecture design

questions.text: What do you think is the most important quality of good code?

options.text: Just needs to solve practical problems
Easy for team members to understand

questions.text: When choosing technology, you prefer to?

options.text: Try the latest and coolest technology
Choose technology that best showcases the product
Choose the best performance and scalability

questions.text: What type of project do you prefer to participate in?
What gives you the most sense of achievement at work?

options.text: Tackling difficult problems with the team

questions.text: How do you view code comments?

options.text: Good code should be self-explanatory, write fewer comments
Comments are important for team understanding
Complex logic must have detailed comments
As long as it runs, comments are optional

questions.text: When encountering performance issues, what would you do?

options.text: Analyze bottlenecks deeply and optimize systematically
Optimize parts that users can perceive first
Research various optimization algorithms and techniques

questions.text: When a project enters a stable phase, what would you most like to do?

options.text: Explore new approaches that could take the product to the next level
Review the codebase to make it cleaner and more concise
Improve monitoring and backup systems for better reliability
Gather user feedback to optimize the workflow

questions.text: If you could keep one tech book on your desk, which would it be?

options.text: "The Elements of User Experience" - Product Design Thinking

questions.text: What's your attitude toward unit testing?

options.text: Essential, it's a guarantee of code quality
Too time-consuming, rapid iteration is more important
Tests should also be written elegantly and clearly
Write them if team standards require

questions.text: What kind of problems do you prefer to solve?

options.text: How people interact with and use products

questions.text: When starting a new project, what would you do?

options.text: Set up a complete development environment first
Discuss technical solutions with the team

questions.text: When designing APIs, what do you focus on most?
When facing technical debt, what would you do?

options.text: Make a plan to refactor gradually
If it works, focus on new features first
Rewrite it into a more elegant version

questions.text: What do you focus more on in code?
When learning new technologies, you tend to?

options.text: Study principles and source code deeply
Get hands-on quickly with a project

questions.text: What kind of code can you least tolerate?

options.text: Lack of testing, prone to errors

questions.text: How do you view technical documentation?

options.text: Detailed documentation is key to project success
Concise and clear, highlighting key points
Focus on user scenarios and use cases
Team collaboration to maintain and update

questions.text: What kind of programming experience do you enjoy more?

options.text: Real-time discussion of ideas with colleagues
Quick feedback when people try your features

questions.text: For open source projects, you prefer to?

options.text: Contribute new features and innovative ideas

questions.text: What do you think good software should be?

options.text: Easy to learn and use, minimal friction

questions.text: When encountering difficult problems, what would you do?
What kind of system would you prefer to maintain?
What kind of development tools do you prefer?

options.text: Standard tools used uniformly by the team

questions.text: What kind of work pace do you prefer?

options.text: Fast trial and error, agile development

questions.text: What do you think technological innovation should be?
You bump into a tech expert at a coffee shop. What would you most want to chat about?

options.text: What interesting technologies they're researching lately
How to balance technical debt and business requirements
How to build highly available system architecture
How to create products users truly love
